datafield.subfield: sponsored by the American Folklife Center ; assisted by the National Council for the Traditional Arts.
13 sound tape reels: analog, 7 1/2 ips, double track, mono., 10 in.

Documentation of the monthly 1978 Neptune Concert Series, which consists of manuscript materials, sound recordings, and photographs of performances of Irish music, French-Canadian folk music and contradance, Arab music and dance, bluegrass music, zydeco music, country music, and gospel music recorded live outdoors on Neptune Plaza in front of the Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, at concerts from April through September 1978, sponsored by the American Folklife Center and the National Council for the Traditional Arts.
Archive of Folk Culture (Library of Congress)
National Council for the Traditional Arts,

publicationstmt.publisher: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to the Collections in the Archive of Folk Culture

did.head: Collection Summary

physdesc.label: Extent (Sound Recordings)
physdesc.extent: 13 sound tape reels: analog, 7 1/2 ips, double track, mono., 10 in.

did.abstract: Documentation of the monthly 1978 Neptune Concert Series, which consists of manuscript materials, sound recordings, and photographs of performances of Irish music, French-Canadian folk music and contradance, Arab music and dance, bluegrass music, zydeco music, country music, and gospel music recorded live outdoors on Neptune Plaza in front of the Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, at concerts from April through September 1978, sponsored by the American Folklife Center and the National Council for the Traditional Arts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The 1978 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection consists of manuscript and print materials, audio recordings, and graphic materials that document the 1978 concert series sponsored by the American Folklife Center. The annual series, which began in 1977, features the presentation of folk traditions from many cultures. The concerts took place on the Neptune Plaza at the front of the Jefferson Building of the Library of Congress between April and September. Adverse weather conditions sometimes forced the concerts indoors. The 1978 series was produced with the assistance of the National Council for the Traditional Arts.

The 1978 season consisted of the following:
Date Performers Place of Origin Subject
April 28 Joe and Antoinette McKenna Ireland Irish music
May 11 Graham Townsend and Maple Sugar Canada French-Canadian music and contradance
May 25 The Arabic Dancers Virginia Middle Eastern music, stick dance, belly dance
June 29 Buck White and the Down Home Boys Tennessee Bluegrass and country music
July 27 The Lawtell Playboys Louisiana Zydeco music
August 31 John Ashby and the Old Time Virginia String Band Viginia Old-Time music
September 28 Mentrotone Baptist Church Singers Washington, D.C Gospel music

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: Documentation created and accessioned by the American Folklife Center in 1978.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Organizations
controlaccess.corpname: Archive of Folk Culture (Library of Congress)
National Council for the Traditional Arts, sponsor.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Listening and viewing access to the collection is unrestricted. Duplication of the materials requires prior permission of the Center and may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 1978 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection (AFC 1978/004), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

row.entry: Presentation of French-Canadian folk dance and music, with audience participation in contradance. Photographs: Folders 6-7; sound recordings: LWO 12216 R1-2 [AFS 19281 - AFS 19282].

Arab music and dance presentation. Female dancer performs raks beledi (country dance) or raks sharqi (oriental dance). She also dances with a man dressed in traditional clothes and carrying a stick, although there is no documentation of him performing raks al tahtib (stick dance). Photographs and slides: Folders 9-10, Envelopes 3-4; sound recording: LWO 12226.
